TEXT.English: [TAB]In the medieval Arab world, the funduq was a commercial building found in many trading hubs. It functioned as a caravan house, but often also as a specialized shopping center. [PARAGRAPH:1]In modern Arabic funduq refers to a hotel.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The people of the Principality of Antioch were predominantly Armenians and Greek Orthodox Christians, with a few Muslims outside the city itself. Most of the crusaders who settled there were of Norman origin and/or from southern Italy, as were the first rulers of the principality who surrounded themselves with their own loyal subjects. There were few Roman Catholics apart from the Crusaders who set up the Principality, even though the city was turned into a Latin Patriarchate in 1100.

Außer den Kreuzfahrern, die das Fürstentum gründeten, gab es nur wenige Katholiken, obwohl die Stadt im Jahr 1100 in ein Lateinisches Patriarchat umgewandelt wurde.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Divan or diwan was a high governmental body in a number of Islamic states, or its chief official. TEXT.English: [TAB]Yam is a supply point route messenger system employed and extensively used and expanded by Genghis Khan and used by his descendants, including the Timurids. [PARAGRAPH:1]Relay stations were used to give food, shelter and spare horses for Mongol armies messengers. Genghis Khan gave special attention to Yam because Mongol armies traveled very fast, so their messengers had to be even faster, covering 200–300 km per day. It was used to speed up the process of information and intelligence.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Chancery is a general term for a medieval writing office, responsible for the production of official documents. The crusaders brought this institution to the Levant. In the Principality of Antioch, the office was responsible for producing all documents pertaining to the administration of the principality. One office holder in the Antiochene chancery was Walter the Chancellor, who wrote the only early history of the state. [PARAGRAPH:1]In the Kingdom of Jerusalem, the chancery produced hundreds of documents. The chancellor of Jerusalem was one of the highest posts in the kingdom. One famous chancellor was the chronicler William of Tyre.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A caravanserai was a roadside inn where travelers could rest and recover from the day's journey. Caravanserais supported the flow of commerce, information, and people across the network of trade routes covering Asia, North Africa, and South-Eastern Europe. [PARAGRAPH:1]Most typically a caravanserai was a building with a square or rectangular walled exterior, with a single portal wide enough to permit large or heavily laden beasts such as camels to enter. The courtyard was almost always open to the sky, and the inside walls of the enclosure were outfitted with a number of identical stalls, bays, niches, or chambers to accommodate merchants and their servants, animals, and merchandise. [PARAGRAPH:1]Caravanserais provided water for human and animal consumption, washing, and ritual ablutions. Sometimes they even had elaborate baths. They also kept fodder for animals and had shops for travellers where they could acquire new supplies. In addition, there could be shops where merchants could dispose of some of their goods.

TEXT.German: [TAB]Eine Karawanserei war ein Gasthaus am Straßenrand, in dem Reisende sich ausruhen und von der Tagesreise erholen konnten. [PARAGRAPH:1]Am typischsten war eine Karawanserei ein Gebäude mit einer quadratischen oder rechteckigen Außenwand und einem einzigen Portal, das breit genug war, um großen oder schwer beladenen Tieren wie Kamelen den Zutritt zu ermöglichen. Der Hof war fast immer zum Himmel hin offen und die Innenwände der Umzäunung waren mit einer Reihe identischer Stände, Erker, Nischen oder Kammern ausgestattet, um Händler und ihre Diener, Tiere und Waren unterzubringen. Darüber hinaus könnte es Geschäfte geben, in denen Händler einen Teil ihrer Waren abgeben könnten.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Hand weaving of Persian carpets and kilims has been an important element of the tribal crafts of many of the subregions of Persia. Examples of carpet types are the Lavar Kerman carpet from Kerman and the Seraband rug from Arak.[PARAGRAPH:1]An important innovation in weaving that was developed in the Muslim world during the Islamic Golden Age was the introduction of foot pedals to operate a loom. TEXT.English: [TAB]The traditions of Sindhi craftwork reflect the cumulative influence of 5000 years of invaders and settlers, whose various modes of art were eventually assimilated into the culture. The elegant floral and geometrical designs that decorate everyday objects—whether of clay, metal, wood, stone or fabric—can be traced to Muslim influence.[PARAGRAPH:2]Though chiefly an agricultural and pastoral province, Sindh has a reputation for ajraks, pottery, leatherwork, carpets, textiles, and silk cloths which, in design and finish, are matchless. The chief articles produced are blankets, coarse cotton cloth (soosi), camel fittings, metalwork, lacquered work, enamel, gold and silver embroidery. Hala is famous for pottery and tiles; Boobak for carpets; Nasirpur, Gambat and Thatta for cotton lungees and khes. Other popular crafts include the earthenware of Johi, the metal vessels of Shikarpur, the relli, embroidery and leather articles of Tharparkar, and the lacquered work of Kandhkot.

TEXT.English: [TAB]After the fall of the Roman Empire, the focus of alchemical development moved to the Arab Empire and the Islamic civilization. Much more is known about Islamic alchemy as it was better documented; indeed, most of the earlier writings that have come down through the years were preserved as Arabic translations.[PARAGRAPH:1]The study of alchemy and chemistry often overlapped in the early Islamic world, but later there were disputes between the traditional alchemists and the practical chemists who discredited alchemy. Muslim chemists and alchemists were the first to employ the experimental scientific method (as practised in modern chemistry), while Muslim alchemists also developed theories on the transmutation of metals, the philosopher's stone and the Takwin (artificial creation of life in the laboratory), like in later medieval European alchemy, though these alchemical theories were rejected by practical Muslim chemists from the 9th century onwards.[PARAGRAPH:1]Early Islamic chemists such as Jabir ibn Hayyan, Al-Kindi and Al-Razi contributed key chemical discoveries, including: distillation apparatus (such as the alembic, still, and retort), the hydrochloric, sulfuric, nitric and acetic acids, soda and potash, purified distilled alcohol, aqua regia, perfumery and many more chemical substances and apparatus.

TEXT.English: [TAB]An orda (also orda, ordu, ordo, ordon) or horde was an historical sociopolitical and military structure found on the Eurasian Steppe, usually associated with the Turkic raiders and Mongols. This entity can be seen as regional equivalent of a clan or a tribe. Some successful ordas gave rise to khanates. Ordu or Ordo also means the Mongolian court. In Mongolian language, the Government Palace (Mongolia) is literally called Zasgiin gazriin ordon.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Public baths originated from a communal need for cleanliness. Public baths have also become incorporated into the social system as meeting places.[PARAGRAPH:1]Cleanliness is an important part of Islam, including Qur'anic verses that teach how to achieve ritual cleanliness. Ritual ablution is also very important, as observed by the practices of wudu (partial ablution), ghusl (full ablution), and tayammum (water-free alternative with sand).

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Dwarakadheesh temple is a Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Krishna, who is worshipped here by the name Dwarkadhish, or 'King of Dwarka'. It is situated at Dwarka, Gujarat, which is believed to have been built after the historic Dvarka city, the Kingdom of Krishna himself which submerged in to the ocean after the Mahabharata war. The main shrine of the 5-storied building, supported by 72 pillars, is known as Jagat Mandir or Nija Mandir, and is believed to be 2500 years old. The Dwarkadhish Temple is Pushti Marg Temple hence it follows the guidelines and rituals created by Shree Vallabacharya and Shree Vitheleshnathji.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A khachkar is a cross-bearing carved memorial stele covered with rosettes and botanical motifs, characteristic of Armenian art and found in Armenia. The most common reason for erecting a khachkar was for votive reasons - for the salvation of the soul of either a living or a deceased person. They were also erected for other reasons, such as to commemorate a military victory, construction of a church, or as a form of protection from natural disasters. [PARAGRAPH:1]The first true khachkars appeared in the 9th century, during the time of Armenian revival after liberation from Arab rule. The oldest khachkar with a known date was carved in 879. Erected in Garni, it is dedicated to queen Katranide, the wife of king Ashot I Bagratuni. The peak of the khachkar carving art was between the 12th and the 14th centuries. The art declined during the Mongol invasion at the end of the 14th century.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A reliquary is a container for relics. These may be the physical remains of saints, such as bones, pieces of clothing, or some object associated with saints or other religious figures. The use of reliquaries became an important part of Christian ritual from at least the 4th century. Relics are venerated in the Oriental Orthodox, Eastern Orthodox, Roman Catholic and some Anglican Churches. Reliquaries provide a means of protecting and displaying relics, which many believe are endowed by God with the grace of miraculous powers. Relics were also important for Muslims, especially the Ottomans. The most important relics of Islam, known as "the Sacred Trusts", are displayed in the Topkapi Palace.

TEXT.English: [TAB]In the medieval Islamic world, the word "Bimaristan" was used to indicate a hospital in the modern sense, an establishment where the ill were welcomed and cared for by qualified staff. In this way, Muslim physicians were the first to make a distinction between a hospital and other different forms of healing temples, sleep temples, hospices, asylums, lazarets and leper-houses, all of which in ancient times were more concerned with isolating the sick and the mad from society "rather than to offer them any way to a true cure." The medieval Bimaristan hospitals are thus considered "the first hospitals" in the modern sense of the word. The first public hospitals, psychiatric hospitals and medical universities were also introduced by medieval Muslim physicians.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Norse sagas are stories about Scandinavian history and folklore. The oldest were preserved for ages through an oral tradition before finally being written down towards the end of the medieval period. Sometimes the tales are realistic; sometimes they are clearly legendary and fantastic. Sagas served as both the formal history of the Viking kings and also the mythical stories of famous heroes. The world of the sagas is strongly pagan. Fate - a dominant concept in the pre-Christian Norse religion - often plays a central role in these tales. [PARAGRAPH:1]Sagas are epic tales in prose, often with stanzas or whole poems in alliterative verse embedded within them. The style tends to be impersonal, providing only terse details with no explanation of "why" - things simply happen, and no one questions Fate. Characters are only briefly introduced, with a few simple adjectives serving to show their personality ("brave warrior", "powerful king", etc.) Relationships between characters are complex. Heroes often have to overcome seemingly impossible tasks; life is generally short and cruel; and the only thing worth pursuing is honor and glory, gained through feats of arms. Any slight or insult to someone's honor has to be avenged, in blood or money. Often the world of the supernatural played a role in the sagas, and figures from the Norse religion could figure prominently. [PARAGRAPH:1]The Kings' Sagas are a group of specific Norse sagas that describe the lives of Scandinavian kings. They were written down between the twelfth and fourteenth centuries after the Vikings had converted to Christianity. These writings are the closest thing that exists to a history of the Scandinavians during the pre-Christian Viking Age, and they have been of inestimable value to historians who study the period. [PARAGRAPH:1]The saga is not strictly a Norse literary technique, and other cultures have produced works similar in form and tone. The epics of Homer, the samurai legends of Japan, and even the cowboy tales of the American West are examples of such works. [PARAGRAPH:1]
TEXT.French: [TAB]Les sagas nordiques sont des récits historiques ou mythologiques de la littérature scandinave. Transmises oralement, elles ont traversé le temps et n'ont été transcrites que vers la fin du Moyen-âge. Certaines d'entre elles relèvent de la chronique, mais le plus souvent, elles revêtent une teneur épique ou légendaire. Elles nous relatent l'histoire et les hauts faits des rois et des héros vikings. L'univers des sagas est clairement païen. Le Destin, notion dominante dans la religion nordique préchrétienne, joue souvent un rôle déterminant dans ce type de récits.[PARAGRAPH:1]Les sagas sont des épopées en prose, structurées en strophes où se mêlent de longs poèmes en vers. Le style est impersonnel, les détails sont donnés succinctement, le principe de causalité est négligé, les événements surgissent spontanément et les différents protagonistes ne doutent jamais de leur Destin. Les personnages sont brossés légèrement, seuls quelques adjectifs suffisent à définir leur personnalité ("guerrier courageux", "puissant roi"). Les relations entre les personnages sont néanmoins complexes. Les héros ont souvent à surmonter des épreuves apparemment impossibles. C'est un univers barbare où la vie ne tient qu'à un fil. Les seules valeurs qui importent vraiment sont l'honneur et la gloire, gagnés sur le champ de bataille. La moindre offense, la plus petite insulte se doivent d'être compensées pécuniairement ou lavées dans le sang. Dans les sagas, le surnaturel joue un rôle important et les dieux du panthéon nordique font souvent leur apparition. [PARAGRAPH:1]Les sagas royales forment un genre particulier. Elles décrivent la vie des rois scandinaves. Elles ont été écrites entre le douzième et le quatorzième siècle, après que les Vikings se soient convertis au christianisme. Ces textes sont ce qui se rapproche le plus d'une histoire de la Scandinavie à l'époque préchrétienne des Vikings, ce qui leur confère une valeur inestimable pour les historiens. [PARAGRAPH:1]La saga n'est pas un genre littéraire purement scandinave. D'autres cultures ont produit des oeuvres au ton et à la forme similaires. Les épopées d'Homère, les légendes des samouraïs japonais, et même les histoires de cow-boys de l'Ouest américain en sont des exemples. [PARAGRAPH:1]
TEXT.German: [TAB]In den nordischen Sagas spiegelt sich die geschichtliche und volkstümliche Entwicklung Skandinaviens wider. Die ältesten dieser Legenden, von denen manche auf wahren Begebenheiten beruhen, andere dagegen eindeutig im Reich der Fabeln anzusiedeln sind, wurden viele Jahrhunderte lang durch mündliche Überlieferung bewahrt, bevor sie gegen Ende des Mittelalters in Schriftform dokumentiert wurden. Sagas dienten sowohl der historischen Dokumentation der Wikingerkönige und ihrer Taten als auch der Darstellung mythischer Geschichten von berühmten Helden. Die Welt der Sagas ist stark heidnisch geprägt, wobei das Schicksal, ein vorherrschendes Element im vorchristlichen nordischen Glauben, oft eine zentrale Rolle spielt. [PARAGRAPH:1]Solche Sagas sind epische Prosaerzählungen, in die oft Strophen oder Gedichte in alliterativer Versform eingearbeitet sind. Stilistisch sind sie eher unpersönlich gehalten und liefern nur wenige Details zum "Warum" - die Dinge passieren einfach und niemand stellt das Schicksal in Frage. Es erfolgt lediglich eine kurze Vorstellung der dargestellten Charaktere mit simplen Adjektiven ("tapferer Krieger", "mächtiger König" etc.). TEXT.English: The Norse sagas are stories about Scandinavian history and folklore. The oldest were preserved for ages through an oral tradition before finally being written down towards the end of the medieval period. Sometimes the tales are realistic; sometimes they are clearly legendary and fantastic. Sagas served as both the formal history of the Viking kings and also the mythical stories of famous heroes. The world of the sagas is strongly pagan. Fate - a dominant concept in the pre-Christian Norse religion - often plays a central role in these tales. [PARAGRAPH:1]Sagas are epic tales in prose, often with stanzas or whole poems in alliterative verse embedded within them. The style tends to be impersonal, providing only terse details with no explanation of "why" - things simply happen, and no one questions Fate. Characters are only briefly introduced, with a few simple adjectives serving to show their personality ("brave warrior", "powerful king", etc.) Relationships between characters are complex. Heroes often have to overcome seemingly impossible tasks; life is generally short and cruel; and the only thing worth pursuing is honor and glory, gained through feats of arms. Any slight or insult to someone's honor has to be avenged, in blood or money. Often the world of the supernatural played a role in the sagas, and figures from the Norse religion could figure prominently. [PARAGRAPH:1]The Legendary Saga, or "Fornaldarsaga" (literally "a tale of times past"), is a Norse saga that takes place in the semi-mythical pre-Christian era of the Vikings. Unlike the Kings' Saga, which is a description of established Viking rulers, the Legendary Saga tells the supernatural and fantastic stories of the Viking heroes. The saga includes mythical creatures such as elves, dwarves, and giants as major characters. Legendary Sagas are believed to have been based on actual historical events, which were later elaborated and made fantastical as they were told and retold through the oral tradition. [PARAGRAPH:1]The Legendary Saga is an enormously valuable source for conveying to us the myths and legends of the ancient Scandinavians prior to their conversion to Christianity. The Legendary Saga also was a huge influence on Tolkien's "Lord of the Rings" fantasy series, and as a result a number of terms which would otherwise be extremely obscure (such as elves and dwarves) have passed into common usage. [PARAGRAPH:1]
TEXT.French: Les sagas nordiques sont des récits historiques ou mythologiques de la littérature médiévale scandinave. Certaines d'entre elles relèvent de la chronique, mais le plus souvent, elles revêtent une teneur épique ou légendaire. Elles nous relatent l'histoire et les hauts faits des rois et des héros vikings. L'univers des sagas est clairement païen. Le Destin, notion dominante dans la religion nordique préchrétienne, joue souvent un rôle déterminant dans ce type de récits.[PARAGRAPH:1]Les sagas sont des épopées en prose, structurées en strophes où se mêlent de longs poèmes en vers. Le style est impersonnel, les détails sont donnés succinctement, le principe de causalité est négligé, les événements surgissent spontanément et les différents protagonistes ne doutent jamais de leur Destin. Les personnages sont brossés légèrement, seuls quelques adjectifs suffisent à définir leur personnalité ("guerrier courageux", "puissant roi"). Les relations entre les personnages sont néanmoins complexes. Les héros ont souvent à surmonter des épreuves apparemment impossibles. C'est un univers barbare où la vie ne tient qu'à un fil. Les seules valeurs qui importent vraiment sont l'honneur et la gloire, gagnés sur le champ de bataille. La moindre offense, la plus petite insulte se doivent d'être compensées pécuniairement ou lavées dans le sang. Dans les sagas, le surnaturel joue un rôle important et les dieux du panthéon nordique font souvent leur apparition.[PARAGRAPH:1]La "Saga légendaire" ou "Fornaldarsaga" (littéralement "récit des temps anciens") est une saga nordique qui se déroule à l'époque préchrétienne et quasi mythique des Vikings. Contrairement aux sagas royales qui relatent la vie des chefs vikings, la"Saga légendaire" nous rapporte la geste fabuleuse des héros mythiques de ce peuple. L'on y croise des créatures fantastiques tels que les Elfes, les Nains ou les Géants. La "Saga légendaire" repose sur des événements historiques qui ont été ensuite, au fil du temps, enjolivés par la tradition orale chargée de les raconter.[PARAGRAPH:1]La "Saga légendaire" est une source inestimable pour accéder à la connaissance des mythes et légendes des anciens peuples scandinaves avant leur conversion au Christianisme. Elle a aussi eu une incontestable influence sur des oeuvres telle que "Le Seigneur des Anneaux" de l'écrivain Tolkien. Grâce à elle enfin, des créatures merveilleuses comme les Nains et les Elfes peuplent désormais notre imaginaire fantastique. [PARAGRAPH:1]

Wenn jemand die Ehre eines anderen auch nur im Mindesten kränkt, muss dieser Frevel gesühnt werden, mit dem Schwert oder mit Geld. Abgesehen von dem Übernatürlichen, das häufig in den nordischen Sagas thematisiert wird, werden auch die Figuren der nordischen Religion besonders hervorgehoben. [PARAGRAPH:1]Die "Vorzeitsagas" oder "Fornaldarsögur" (übersetzt etwa "Erzählung aus vergangener Zeit") sind nordische Sagenerzählungen, die in der halbmythischen vorchristlichen Wikingerzeit spielen. [PARAGRAPH:1]Die Vorzeitsagas gelten als wertvolle Informationsquellen für die Mythen und Legenden der alten Skandinavier vor ihrem Übertritt zum Christentum. TEXT.English: [TAB]The Kaaba is a cube-shaped building in Mecca, and is the most sacred site in Islam. The building predates Islam, and, according to Islamic tradition, the first building at the site was built by Abraham. The building has a mosque built around it, the Masjid al-Haram. All Muslims around the world face the Kaaba during prayers, no matter where they are.[PARAGRAPH:1]One of the Five Pillars of Islam requires every Muslim to perform the Hajj pilgrimage at least once in his or her lifetime if they are able to do so. Multiple parts of the Hajj require pilgrims to walk seven times around the Kaaba in a counter-clockwise direction (as viewed from above). This circumambulation, the Tawaf, is also performed by pilgrims during the Umrah (lesser pilgrimage).

TEXT.English: [TAB]Tannery is a facility where the tanning process is applied to hide to produce leather. TEXT.English: As nomadic tribesmen (and later as cavalry-based conquerors), the Mongolians' survival was dependent upon the quality of their horses and the skill of their riders. A warhorse must be extensively trained if it is to be successfully used in battle. In their natural state, most horses quite sensibly seek to run away from dangerous situations - say, when surrounded by screaming men armed with sharp objects. A cavalryman's horse, on the other hand, needs to be able to suppress this instinct and instead instantly carry out any order given it by its rider - no matter how suicidal. Such training takes time and skill - for both mount and rider. Mongolian stables - built in the ubiquitous Mongolian yurt (or "ger") tents - provide such training.

[TAB]The Church of the Holy Sepulchre, also called the Church of the Resurrection by Eastern Christians, is a Christian church within the walled Old City of Jerusalem. The site is venerated by many Christians as Golgotha, where the New Testament says that Jesus was crucified, and is said to also contain the place where Jesus was buried (the sepulchre). The church has been an important pilgrimage destination since at least the 4th century, as the purported site of the death and resurrection of Jesus. Today it also serves as the headquarters of the Greek Orthodox Patriarch of Jerusalem, while control of the building is shared between several Christian churches and secular entities in complicated arrangements essentially unchanged for centuries.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A souq or souk is a commercial quarter in an Arab or Berber city. TEXT.English: [TAB]Oman has a rich trading history dating back to ancient times. Secluded but strategically located between Mesopotamia and India, Oman extensively traded with both. The kingdom's most important trade goods were frankincense, marble and copper. Pliny the Elder wrote that control of the incese route had made the South Arabians one of the richest people in the world.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Charbagh or Chahar Bagh (Persian: "four gardens") is a Persian and Indo-Persian quadrilateral garden layout based on the four gardens of Paradise mentioned in the Quran. The quadrilateral garden is divided by walkways or flowing water into four smaller parts. They are found in countries throughout Western Asia, North Africa, the former Islamic Andalusia and South Asia including Iran and India.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Norias can be built faster than aqueducts and will promote your growth, but they are only available later in game and can only be built on a river.[PARAGRAPH:2]A noria is a machine for lifting water into a small aqueduct, either for the purpose of irrigation or, in at least one known instance, to feed seawater into a saltern.[PARAGRAPH:2]Muslim engineers used norias to discharge water into aqueducts which carried the water to towns and fields. Some of the norias used in the medieval Islamic world were as large as 20 meters in diameter, the one in Hama being a surviving example still used in modern times. It has 120 water collection compartments and could raise as much as 95 litres of water per minute.

TEXT.English: [TAB]On 12 December 2017, the Portuguese Navy commemorated the 700th anniversary of its official creation by King Denis of Portugal. Tracing its origins back to the 12th century, it is the oldest continuously serving navy in the world. The Navy played a key role at the beginning and during the great voyages of the Age of Discoveries in the 15th and 16th centuries. The result of this technical and scientific discoveries led Portugal to develop advanced ships, including the caravel, new and more sophisticated types of carracks for interoceanic travel and the oceanic galleon, and to find the sea route to the East and routes to South America and Northern North America.

TEXT.German: [TAB]Am 12. Dezember 2017 feierte die portugiesische Marine den 700. Jahrestag ihrer offiziellen Gründung durch König Denis von Portugal. Ihre Ursprünge reichen bis ins 12. Jahrhundert zurück und sie ist die älteste ununterbrochen im Dienst befindliche Marine der Welt. Die Marine spielte zu Beginn und während der großen Reisen des Zeitalters der Entdeckungen im 15. und 16. Jahrhundert eine Schlüsselrolle. TEXT.English: [TAB]Bidriware is a metal handicraft from the city of Bidar in Karnataka. It was developed in the 14th century C.E. during the rule of the Bahmani Sultans. The term "bidriware" originates from the township of Bidar, which is still the chief center of production. The metal used is white brass that is blackened and inlaid with silver.
